title: Organ and Tissue Donation
field_search_summary_text: Learn the basics of the organ donation process for a deceased person.

title: Overcome challenges with home dialysis
field_search_summary_text: There can be a lot of challenges when doing home dialysis, but you can overcome them! Learn about common challenges and concerns, and how you can prepare for them.

title: Preparing for home dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Before starting home dialysis, your training team will check your home, help set up your treatment space, arrange needed surgery, and provide information on payment options.

title: Your care partner for home dialysis
field_search_summary_text: As a care partner, you can help in many ways, like setting up treatment space, managing side effects, and offering support. Everyone’s needs are different, your role may vary.

title: Nutrition and home dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Learn about nutrition and home dialysis, including what nutrients, vitamins, and minerals you need to eat or limit, and which foods have them.

title: Home dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Learn about home dialysis, the different treatment types, the possible benefits and downsides of home dialysis, and how to decide if home dialysis is right for you.

title: Living well with home dialysis
field_search_summary_text: You may need to make many changes to your daily schedule, or overall life once you start home dialysis. Learn what your day-to-day life may be like on home dialysis including changes to your schedule, what you eat, exercise, and physical and mental health.

title: Hematuria (Blood in the Urine) In Adults
field_search_summary_text: Hematuria means blood is in the urine. There are many causes in adults, including cancer, infection, and kidney stones. Testing and follow-up are key.

title: Hematuria (Blood in the Urine) in Children
field_search_summary_text: There are many causes of hematuria (blood in urine) in children, including infection, kidney stones, and heavy exercise. Testing and follow-up are key.

title: Pain Medicines and Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Using pain medicines with kidney disease comes with risks. Read more to learn what your options are to treat your pain while maximizing your safety.

title: Risk Factors for Chronic Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Learn about risk factors for chronic kidney disease (CKD). Regular tests and early detection can help manage CKD.

title: Statins
field_search_summary_text: Statins help lower heart disease and stroke risk, even without high cholesterol. Discover how they benefit people living with kidney disease.

title: Catheter-Related Bloodstream Infection (CRBSI)
field_search_summary_text: Catheter-related bloodstream Infection (CRBSI) can be serious. Causes, treatment and prevention are covered.

title: COVID-19 and Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: The impact of COVID-19 in people with chronic kidney disease (CKD), kidney failure, and kidney transplant recipients, covering symptoms, risk factors, prevention, and treatment options.

title: Living Donor Finances and Insurance
field_search_summary_text: Costs related to living donation can be covered by a recipient’s health insurance and financial assistance programs. National & state laws also protect living donors’ rights.

title: What to Expect After Donation
field_search_summary_text: Life doesn’t change much after donating. After recovering from surgery, donors are able to return to work, physical activity and are able to eat a regular diet.

title: Goodpasture Syndrome
field_search_summary_text: Goodpasture Syndrome is a rare autoimmune disease affecting the kidneys and lungs. Learn about causes, diagnosis, and treatment.

title: High Phosphorus (Hyperphosphatemia)
field_search_summary_text: High phosphorus in the blood is often caused by kidney disease and increases the risk of many health problems. Treatment includes diet changes and medication.

title: Urinalysis (urine test)
field_search_summary_text: A urinalysis tests pee to detect issues like infections, kidney disease, and diabetes for early diagnosis and treatment.

title: SGLT2 inhibitors
field_search_summary_text: SGLT2 inhibitors are medicines that can help improve kidney and heart health for people living with CKD. They can also help people with type 2 diabetes manage their blood sugar.

title: Vaccines for Children with Advanced Chronic Kidney Disease, Kidney Failure, or Kidney Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Vaccines protect children from serious diseases by teaching the immune system how to recognize and fight harmful germs.

title: Vaccines for Adults with Advanced Chronic Kidney Disease, Kidney Failure, or Kidney Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Recommended vaccines for adults with advanced chronic kidney disease, kidney failure, or kidney transplants.

title: Long-Term Risks of Living Donation
field_search_summary_text: Donating your kidney is typically very safe, however you should be aware of the potential long-term health issues that you could be at risk for developing.

title: Kidney Function
field_search_summary_text: The kidneys perform important functions that keep the body in balance, such as filtering blood, regulating blood pressure, and removing waste. Simple lab tests can check kidney function to help find problems early.

title: Diet after kidney transplant
field_search_summary_text: After transplant, most patients will have more freedom with their diet, but healthy choices and food safety are important.

title: Vaccines and Kidney Disease: Stay Protected and Stay Healthy
field_search_summary_text: Vaccines help protect people with CKD from serious complications from diseases. Learn about safety, effectiveness, and addressing concerns with your healthcare provider.

title: Overweight and Obesity
field_search_summary_text: Overweight and obesity put stress on the kidneys and worsen health. Managing weight can help protect kidney function and your overall health.

title: Glomerulonephritis
field_search_summary_text: Glomerulonephritis happens when the kidneys' blood filters (glomeruli) become inflamed and scarred. It has different causes.

title: Sexual Health and Kidney Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Sexual health typically improves after a kidney transplant.

title: Pregnancy, Fertility, and Babies after a Kidney Transplant
field_search_summary_text: After kidney transplant, your ability to have a child can return quickly. For women, plan any pregnancy with your care team to keep yourself, your kidney, and your baby healthy.

title: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL)
field_search_summary_text: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive procedure for treating kidney and ureter stones. It uses high-energy shock waves to break stones into tiny fragments that can be passed naturally through urine.

title: 6-Step Guide to Protecting Kidney Health
field_search_summary_text: Learn more about kidney disease, your risk, and how to prevent it.

title: GLP-1 Receptor Agonists (GLP-1 RAs)
field_search_summary_text: GLP-1 RAs help slow CKD and lower heart disease risk for people with type 2 diabetes and/or obesity, but it’s important to weigh risks and benefits.

title: Paying for your medicines and lowering your medication costs
field_search_summary_text: An overview of different programs available to help you pay for your medicines and lower your medication costs.

title: Living Donor Surgery and Risks
field_search_summary_text: There are two types of living donor surgery. If you’re thinking about donating, you should be aware of surgery risks and know who to talk to if you have questions or concerns.

title: Genetics and Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Genetics can play a role in kidney disease risk. However, other factors can also contribute to risk.

title: Making the Decision to Donate
field_search_summary_text: There’s a lot to think about when deciding to donate a kidney. You need to know about potential issues and who to turn to for help with your decision.

title: Hemodialysis and Your Diet
field_search_summary_text: Diet is a key part of your hemodialysis treatment. You may need to limit fluids and change your intake of some foods and condiments.

title: Immunosuppressants (Anti-rejection Medicines)
field_search_summary_text: Immunosuppressants (anti-rejection medicines), are medicines that keep kidney transplants from being attacked by the immune system.

title: Life with a Kidney Transplant
field_search_summary_text: After a kidney transplant, take anti-rejection meds, attend check-ups, and maintain a healthy lifestyle. Report symptoms and follow all care instructions.

title: Caribbean: Fluid and the Kidney Diet
Caribbean: Protein and the Kidney Diet
Caribbean: Sodium and the Kidney Diet
Caribbean: Phosphorus and the Kidney Diet
Caribbean: Potassium and the Kidney Diet
Hemodialysis
field_search_summary_text: Hemodialysis is a life-saving treatment for kidney failure that removes waste and extra fluids from the blood and regulates blood pressure.

title: Financial and Insurance Changes: What Dialysis Patients Should Know About Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Learn about financial changes post-transplant, including insurance updates, Medicare, Medicaid, and out-of-pocket costs. Essential info for managing expenses.

title: Getting a kidney transplant
field_search_summary_text: To get a kidney transplant, you need to contact a transplant center ("referral”), complete an evaluation with the transplant team, and be approved for transplant.

title: DASH Diet Menu
field_search_summary_text: Sample DASH Diet Menu includes balanced meals like pumpkin pancakes, pasta salad, and chicken salad wraps. Emphasizes low sodium, potassium, and balanced nutrients.

title: Plant-Based Diet and Kidney Health
field_search_summary_text: Eating more plant-based foods like vegetables and grains instead of red meat can help prevent and slow kidney disease, diabetes, high blood pressure, and heart disease.

title: Lupus Nephritis
field_search_summary_text: Lupus nephritis is a disease that affects the kidneys, making it difficult for them to clean blood well.

title: IgA Nephropathy (IgAN)
field_search_summary_text: IgAN is a form of kidney damage. The exact cause is unknown. Read more about risk factors, symptoms, tests, complications, and treatment options.

title: The Kidney Transplant Waitlist
field_search_summary_text: The transplant waitlist matches deceased donors with kidney patients for a transplant. How long it takes to get one depends many factors, but it can take 2-5 years or more.

title: Metabolic Acidosis
field_search_summary_text: Metabolic acidosis is too much acid in the blood. It is more common in people with advanced CKD and can be life-threatening if not treated appropriately.

title: Getting a Living Donor Kidney Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Explore the benefits, types, and process of getting a kidney from a living donor, including costs, finding a donor, and key questions for your healthcare team.

title: Becoming a Living Donor
field_search_summary_text: Living kidney donation allows a healthy person to donate one kidney. It offers benefits like a shorter wait and better match for the recipient.

title: Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)
field_search_summary_text: Acute kidney injury (AKI) occurs when kidneys suddenly lose their ability to filter waste from the blood, developing within hours or days. It replaces the term 'acute renal failure.'

title: The Heart and Kidney Connection
field_search_summary_text: Your heart and kidneys are two important organs in your body. They work together to keep you healthy. When one is affected, the other is too.

title: Nutrition and Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Post-transplant, maintaining a balanced diet is crucial for kidney health. Your dietary needs might change due to medications, so consult with your healthcare team for personalized advice.

title: Palliative Care Helps Patients with Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Palliative care offers support for CKD patients by managing pain, aiding communication with doctors, and helping cope with stress.

title: Living Donation Resources
field_search_summary_text: Find resources for living donation: organizations for paired donation, financial aid, and community support, including the National Kidney Registry, NLDAC, and Living Donors Online.

title: Other Financial Resources
field_search_summary_text: Explore financial resources for medical and dental care: free flights from Air Care Alliance and Angel Flight, low-cost dental care through ADA and NFDH, and SSDI/SSI for income support.

title: How to Increase Calories in Your CKD Diet
field_search_summary_text: When you have CKD, adjusting your diet can make it hard to get enough calories. This guide offers tips to ensure you meet your energy needs while eating healthily.

title: Antiperspirants
field_search_summary_text: Concerns about antiperspirants causing kidney disease are based on outdated information. Skin absorption of aluminum from antiperspirants is minimal and not harmful.

title: Medigap Plans
field_search_summary_text: Medigap Plans help cover costs Medicare doesn‚Äôt, like copayments and deductibles. Offered by private insurers, they vary in cost and coverage.

title: Assistance Programs Offered by Pharmaceutical Companies
field_search_summary_text: Pharmaceutical companies offer prescription assistance for dialysis and transplant medications. Contact them for eligibility and updates.

title: Diabetes After a Transplant
field_search_summary_text: New-onset diabetes (NODAT) can occur after a transplant due to anti-rejection meds. It increases risk of high blood sugar, impacting heart, eyes, and nerves.

title: About Diabetes: Are You At Risk?
field_search_summary_text: Diabetes affects sugar regulation in your body. Learn about types, risk factors, warning signs, and steps to manage or prevent diabetes.

title: Medicare
field_search_summary_text: Medicare covers dialysis and kidney transplant costs for all ages. Includes Part A (hospital care), Part B (doctor services), and Part D (prescriptions).

title: Children and Teenager's Health
field_search_summary_text: Find resources on kidney health for children and teens, including prevention tips, chronic kidney disease management, and guidance for parents and caregivers.

title: Quality of Life with Diabetes
field_search_summary_text: Managing diabetes effectively involves daily self-care, including monitoring blood sugar, taking medications, and meeting with diabetes educators.

title: Tips for Choosing a Dialysis Clinic
field_search_summary_text: Choosing a dialysis clinic involves evaluating location, distance, schedule, and quality of care to find the right facility for your needs.

title: Family and Caregiver Resources
field_search_summary_text: Find valuable resources for caregivers and families, including support, information, and tools for managing caregiving challenges.

title: The Dialysis Facility Compare (DFC) Star Program
field_search_summary_text: The Dialysis Facility Compare (DFC) Star Program rates dialysis centers from 1 to 5 stars based on patient health to help compare local facilities.

title: Healthy Hydration and Your Kidneys
field_search_summary_text: Healthy hydration means having the right amount of water in your body. Too little water is dehydration, and too much is fluid overload.

title: APOL1-Mediated Kidney Disease (AMKD)
field_search_summary_text: Learn about APOL1-Mediated Kidney Disease (AMKD), its causes, symptoms, and treatments. Find information on genetic testing, complications, and management.

title: High Kidney Donor Profile Index (KDPI)
field_search_summary_text: Learn about high KDPI and IRD kidneys for transplant, including their benefits, risks, and how they might offer faster access to a kidney transplant.

title: Kidney Failure
field_search_summary_text: Kidney failure means your kidneys no longer work well. With 85-90% function gone, dialysis or a transplant is needed. Symptoms include fatigue, swelling, and more.

title: Hyponatremia (low sodium level in the blood)
field_search_summary_text: Hyponatremia: Learn about low sodium in the blood, its symptoms, causes, and treatment options for better health management.

title: Citrus
field_search_summary_text: Citrus fruits are superfoods high in vitamin C and pectin. Monitor potassium intake with CKD, consult your dietitian for safe citrus consumption.

title: Superfoods
field_search_summary_text: Explore kidney-friendly superfoods: discover new recipes, enjoy healthy twists on favorites, and make every meal nutritious for your kidney health.

title: Açai Berries
field_search_summary_text: Açai berries are rich in antioxidants and may support heart health. They are suitable for CKD and dialysis patients, but monitor potassium intake. Consult your dietitian.

title: Eggs
field_search_summary_text: Eggs provide high-quality protein and essential nutrients. They‚Äôre low in sodium and potassium but contain phosphorus. Safe to eat with kidney disease; consult your dietitian.

title: Shellfish
field_search_summary_text: Shellfish like crab, lobster, and shrimp are rich in protein, iron, and omega-3s. They‚Äôre low in calories but high in cholesterol. Safe to eat with kidney disease; check with your dietitian.

title: Cherries
field_search_summary_text: Cherries, available fresh, frozen, or dried, add flavor to many dishes. They're high in vitamin C, fiber, and antioxidants. Sweet cherries are high in potassium; sour cherries are lower.

title: Yogurt
field_search_summary_text: Yogurt is a creamy dairy product made by fermenting milk. It can be plain, mixed with fruit, in smoothies, or dips. Types include Greek and plant-based.

title: Flax and Chia Seeds
field_search_summary_text: Flax and chia seeds are nutrient-rich and available year-round. Store them in a sealed container in the freezer to prevent spoilage. Enjoy them in cereals, yogurt, salads, baked goods, or smoothies.

title: Health Equity and Chronic Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Health equity means providing resources based on need, not treating everyone the same. Inequities in CKD arise from factors like race, insurance, and social determinants.

title: Social Determinants of Health and Chronic Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Social factors like income, education, and access to care affect CKD risk. Racial disparities in CKD stem from historical inequities, not race itself.

title: Kidney Disease Cookbooks
field_search_summary_text: Explore kidney-healthy cookbooks and online resources for dialysis patients, featuring diverse recipes, dietary tips, and nutritional guidance.

title: Managed Care: Questions and Answers
field_search_summary_text: Understanding managed care plans for ESRD patients helps in making informed decisions about treatment, costs, and coverage. Get the key facts here.

title: Insurance Resources
field_search_summary_text: Find Insurance resources here

title: Hydronephrosis
field_search_summary_text: Hydronephrosis is a condition that occurs when a kidney swells and can't get rid of pee (urine) like it should

title: Can my GFR get better?
field_search_summary_text: Learn about eGFR, a key indicator of kidney health. Understand what your eGFR means, how it's calculated, and steps to maintain healthy kidney function.

title: Chronic Kidney Disease: Quality Care Begins with Measurement
Creatinine
field_search_summary_text: Creatinine is a waste from protein and muscle breakdown. High levels can signal kidney issues. This test helps assess kidney function.

title: Stage 5 Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
field_search_summary_text: Stage 5 CKD is kidney failure. Your kidneys work at less than 15% capacity, needing dialysis or a transplant. Common symptoms include fatigue, swelling, and shortness of breath.

title: Stage 4 Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
field_search_summary_text: Stage 4 CKD means severe kidney function loss. Symptoms include fatigue, swelling, and nausea. Regular check-ups and lifestyle changes are crucial for managing it.

title: Stage 3b Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
field_search_summary_text: Stage 3b CKD means moderate to severe kidney function loss. Symptoms include fatigue, swelling, and nausea. Regular checkups and lifestyle changes can help manage it.

title: Stage 3a Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
field_search_summary_text: Stage 3a CKD: Learn about mild to moderate kidney function loss, symptoms, lifestyle changes, diet, medications, and steps to manage and lower your health risks.

title: Stage 2 Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
field_search_summary_text: Stage 2 CKD means mild kidney damage with eGFR 60-89 and albuminuria. Focus on a healthy lifestyle, manage other health issues, and follow your doctor's advice.

title: Stage 1 Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
field_search_summary_text: Stage 1 CKD means eGFR of 90+ with kidney damage like albuminuria, UTIs, or hematuria for 3+ months.

title: Patient Education Library: Infographics
field_search_summary_text: Find patient education infographics related to kidney disease

title: Tests to Check Your Kidney Health
field_search_summary_text: Your healthcare provider will order tests every so often to check on your kidney health. The specific test(s) they order depends on any symptoms you may have and other factors

title: Patient Education Library: Videos
field_search_summary_text: Find patient videos related to kidney disease

title: Patient Education Library: 2-sided Flyers
field_search_summary_text: Find printable patient flyers related to kidney disease

title: Patient Education Library: Brochures
field_search_summary_text: Find printable patient brochures related to kidney disease

title: Non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (nsMRAs)
field_search_summary_text: Non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (nsMRAs) like finerenone help protect kidneys and lower cardiovascular risk. Learn about their uses, effectiveness, and side effects.

title: ACE Inhibitors and ARBs
field_search_summary_text: ACE inhibitors and ARBs help protect your kidneys and heart. They lower blood pressure.

title: Finding More Information About Clinical Trials
field_search_summary_text: Explore essential online resources about clinical trials, including information on phases, terminology, and participation from NIH and other organizations.

title: Pomegranates
field_search_summary_text: Pomegranates are rich in potassium and low in phosphorus and sodium. Check with your healthcare provider to see how much is safe for your kidney disease stage or dialysis type.

title: Diabetes and Kidney Failure (Stage 5)
field_search_summary_text: Diabetes can damage kidneys, leading to failure. Treatment includes dialysis, kidney transplant, and tight control of blood sugar and overall health.

title: Avocados
field_search_summary_text: Avocados are nutrient-dense with 20 vitamins and minerals, low in carbs, high in healthy fats, and good for heart health. They are high in potassium and safe for kidney diets.

title: Potassium
field_search_summary_text: Potassium is vital for body functions, but imbalances can be harmful, especially with kidney disease. High or low levels may cause symptoms like muscle weakness or heart issues.

title: Potassium in Your CKD Diet
field_search_summary_text: Potassium is vital for many body functions, and people with kidney disease must monitor their levels. Learn how to manage potassium intake to stay healthy.

title: Tofu
field_search_summary_text: Tofu is a nutrient-dense plant-based food that's low in phosphorus, potassium, and sodium, making it kidney-friendly. It's versatile in many dishes.

title: Low Phosphorus Cheese
field_search_summary_text: Many cheeses are high in phosphorus and sodium, but some are suitable for kidney disease. Learn which low-phosphorus cheeses you can enjoy safely.

title: Xenotransplantation
field_search_summary_text: Xenotransplantation involves using non-human cells, tissues, or organs, like pig kidneys, to treat human medical conditions. Learn about its uses, successful experiments, and the pros and cons.

title: Milk Alternatives
field_search_summary_text: Plant-based milks from oats, soy, rice, nuts, and seeds are popular alternatives to dairy milk and are easy to find at the grocery store.

title: Children Born With One Kidney
field_search_summary_text: Children with one kidney can lead normal lives but need regular check-ups. Most can play sports with medical advice and protective gear.

title: Prenatal Hydronephrosis (Urinary Tract Dilation)
field_search_summary_text: Prenatal hydronephrosis causes kidney swelling in unborn babies. Most cases resolve without treatment; some may need monitoring or surgery.

title: Sepsis
field_search_summary_text: Sepsis is a life-threatening response to infection or injury. It can cause blood clots, low blood pressure, and prevent oxygen from reaching your kidneys.

title: Healthy Oils and Fats
field_search_summary_text: Learn about the benefits of healthy oils and fats, their importance for kidney-friendly diets, and discover heart-healthy recipes for salad dressings.

title: Fish
field_search_summary_text: Fish is a high-protein, low-fat superfood rich in omega-3 fatty acids, vitamins, and minerals. Learn how fish benefits kidney health and find a tasty salmon recipe.

title: Mpox
field_search_summary_text: Mpox is a rare disease similar to smallpox but milder. Symptoms include a rash, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. Spread through close contact. Treatment focuses on symptom relief.

title: Pruritus (Itchy Skin)
field_search_summary_text: The general term pruritus means very itchy skin caused by a long-term disease, such as chronic kidney disease (CKD). It is also know as CKD-Associate Pruritus

title: Spices
field_search_summary_text: Spices like cinnamon, cumin, and turmeric enhance flavor in dishes. They're safe in cooking but use caution with supplements or large quantities.

title: Nephrotic Syndrome in Children
field_search_summary_text: Nephrotic syndrome in kids causes swelling and protein loss in urine. Managed with meds and a low-sodium diet. Monitoring is crucial for treatment.

title: Proteinuria in Children
field_search_summary_text: Proteinuria in children means too much protein in urine, often due to kidney issues. It can be temporary or a sign of disease. Testing helps determine the cause and treatment.

title: Managing Blood Sugar For Kidney Health
field_search_summary_text: Managing blood sugar is key for kidney health in diabetes. Regular checks, medication, and a balanced diet help prevent kidney damage and slow chronic kidney disease.

title: Diabetes and Your Eyes, Heart, Nerves, Feet, and Kidneys
field_search_summary_text: Diabetes can damage your eyes, heart, nerves, feet, and kidneys due to high blood sugar. Manage diabetes with a proper plan to protect these vital organs.

title: Depression and Dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Depression is common in people who are on dialysis and can affect kidney health, as well as overall well-being.

title: Strawberries
field_search_summary_text: Strawberries are a low-calorie superfood rich in vitamin C, antioxidants, and fiber. They're low in potassium, making them great for CKD diets. Enjoy them fresh or in various dishes!

title: Root Vegetables
field_search_summary_text: Root vegetables like carrots, potatoes, and beets are nutrient-rich and affordable. They include bulbs like onions and garlic. Consult your doctor before using supplements.

title: Broccoli
field_search_summary_text: Broccoli is a nutrient-rich superfood, high in vitamins C and K, and low in calories. It's beneficial for kidney health and suitable for various kidney conditions.

title: Inherited Kidney Diseases
field_search_summary_text: Inherited kidney diseases are genetic conditions that can run in families. They include ADPKD, Alport syndrome, and more. Genetic testing helps in diagnosis and management.

title: Beans
field_search_summary_text: Beans are great for kidney health. They're low in fat, high in fiber, protein, iron, potassium, and magnesium.

title: Nuts and Seeds
field_search_summary_text: Nuts and seeds come in many types. Though they are high in oil, they offer "good fats"

title: Six Healthy Travel Snacks
field_search_summary_text: Healthy travel snacks: unsalted nuts, avocados with crackers, unsweetened dried fruit, hummus with veggies, plain popcorn, and nut butter banana sandwiches.

title: Salt-Free Pizza
field_search_summary_text: Pizza is a great, family-friendly meal that can be healthy, too. And now you can enjoy one without "a-salting" your kidneys!

title: Keep Your Kidneys Healthy: 5 Foods To Avoid
field_search_summary_text: Top 5 tips to reduce salt: read food labels, choose fresh foods, avoid added sodium seasonings, check restaurant sodium info, and gradually adjust to less salt.

title: Top 5 Ways to Stop A-Salting Your Kidneys
field_search_summary_text: Reduce sodium in your diet to protect your kidneys. Read labels, choose fresh foods, avoid salty seasonings, dine out smartly, and adjust to less salt over time.

title: Healthier Holiday Eating
field_search_summary_text: Enjoy a healthier holiday meal with lower sodium. Make dishes from scratch, choose fresh meats, use low-sodium ingredients, and watch your portions.

title: Five Drugs You May Need to Avoid or Adjust if You Have Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Medications can impact your kidneys, especially with chronic kidney disease. Learn which drugs may need adjustments to protect your kidney health.

title: Kidney Stone Diet Plan and Prevention
field_search_summary_text: Learn about managing kidney stones with a specialized diet. Discover the role of hydration, types of kidney stones, and dietary tips for prevention.

title: Kidney Stones
field_search_summary_text: A kidney stone is a hard object that is made from chemicals in the urine.

title: Diabetes and Kidney Disease (Stages 1-4)
field_search_summary_text: Good nutrition helps people with kidney disease stay healthy. If your kidneys are not working so well, some changes in the diet help you feel better.

title: Whole Grains
field_search_summary_text: Whole grains are rich in fiber, vitamins, and minerals. They are great for CKD diets, help with blood pressure, and support heart health.

title: Squash
field_search_summary_text: Winter and summer squashes are great for CKD diets. They include butternut, pumpkin, zucchini, and more. Easy to cook and nutritious!

title: Family History and Kidney Diseases
field_search_summary_text: Family history and social factors can increase the risk of kidney disease. Learn how to manage these risks and take steps to protect your kidney health.

title: Blueberries
field_search_summary_text: Blueberries are nutritious, available year-round, and easy to prepare. Fresh blueberries vary in cost by season, while frozen ones are often more affordable. Just rinse and eat!

title: Apples
field_search_summary_text: Apples are rich in antioxidants and fiber, low in potassium, phosphorus, and sodium, making them kidney-friendly. They suit various kidney conditions and treatments.

title: Tomatoes
field_search_summary_text: Tomatoes are rich in nutrients like lycopene, vitamin A, vitamin C, potassium, and fiber. Check with your doctor about your potassium intake, as it varies by kidney disease stage.

title: Herbs
field_search_summary_text: Herbs add flavor without salt, can be grown easily, and are useful for people with kidney disease.

title: Leafy Green Vegetables
field_search_summary_text: Dark leafy greens like kale, spinach, and bok choy are nutrient-rich, providing vitamins A, C, E, K, and B-vitamins. They also offer iron, magnesium, potassium, and calcium.

title: Kidney Cancer
field_search_summary_text: Kidney cancer starts in the kidneys and can lead to tumors. Symptoms may include blood in urine and back pain. Risk factors include smoking, obesity, and high blood pressure.

title: Carbohydrate Counting with Chronic Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Carbohydrate counting helps manage blood sugar in diabetes. Learn what carbs are, where to find them, and how to plan meals with CKD.

title: Primary Hyperoxaluria Type 1
field_search_summary_text: Primary hyperoxaluria type 1 (PH1) is a rare genetic condition causing high oxalate levels in urine, leading to kidney stones and potential kidney failure.

title: Pandemic Fatigue and You
field_search_summary_text: COVID-19 is a new coronavirus strain causing illness from the common cold to severe diseases. It spreads mainly through respiratory droplets.

title: Kidney Stones in Children and Teens
field_search_summary_text: Kidney stones in kids can cause severe pain. Treatment includes increased fluids, pain relief, and sometimes surgery.

title: Missing Dialysis Treatment Is Dangerous for Your Health
field_search_summary_text: Skipping dialysis can be risky. It can cause fluid overload, high potassium, and high phosphorus levels, leading to severe health problems. Always attend your treatments.

title: Expanded Medicare Coverage of Immunosuppressive Drugs for Kidney Transplant Recipients
field_search_summary_text: Medicare now covers kidney transplant immunosuppressive drugs for life, starting January 1, 2023. Eligibility details and how to enroll.

title: Does Type 2 Diabetes Increase Your Risk for Kidney Disease? Yes
field_search_summary_text: Type 2 diabetes raises the risk of kidney disease, a serious condition. Early testing and managing diabetes are crucial to prevent kidney damage and complications.

title: Informed Choices for Chronic Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Explore the National Kidney Foundation‚Äôs video series on CKD treatment options. Learn about CKD, slowing its progression, and dialysis choices.

title: Post-Infectious Glomerulonephritis (PIGN)
field_search_summary_text: Post-Infectious Glomerulonephritis (PIGN) causes kidney inflammation after infections, leading to symptoms like blood in urine, swelling, and high blood pressure.

title: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
field_search_summary_text: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) means your kidneys slowly get damaged and can't do important jobs like removing waste and keeping blood pressure normal.

title: Bedwetting in Children & Teens: Nocturnal Enuresis
field_search_summary_text: Nocturnal enuresis is bedwetting at night, common in kids and teens. It often resolves on its own. Treatments include alarms, meds, and lifestyle changes.

title: Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR) in Infants & Children
field_search_summary_text: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is when urine flows back from the bladder to the kidneys. It can lead to infections. Treatment may include antibiotics or surgery.

title: Stopping or Not Starting Dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Choosing not to start or stop dialysis, known as conservative care, focuses on easing symptoms and improving comfort without aiming to cure the illness.

title: Choosing Dialysis: Which type is right for me?
field_search_summary_text: There are 3 main types of dialysis: in-center hemodialysis, home hemodialysis, and peritoneal dialysis. Learn the pros and cons of each treatment.

title: Ultrafiltration
field_search_summary_text: Ultrafiltration is the process of removing fluid from the body during dialysis. It helps achieve target dry weight by removing excess fluid safely.

title: Peritonitis
field_search_summary_text: Peritonitis is an infection of the peritoneum, which can occur during peritoneal dialysis. Symptoms include abdominal pain and fever. Prompt treatment is crucial.

title: Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis (dRTA): What is dRTA and how is it diagnosed?
field_search_summary_text: dRTA is a kidney disorder causing acid buildup in the blood. It can be inherited or caused by other conditions. Diagnosis involves blood, urine, and genetic tests.

title: dRTA: How is it Treated?
field_search_summary_text: Treating distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA) involves using alkali agents to balance blood acid levels. This helps manage related issues like kidney stones and bone problems.

title: Treatment for C3G
field_search_summary_text: Treatment for C3G includes managing blood pressure, proteinuria, and cholesterol with medications, lifestyle changes, and emerging therapies.

title: Pasta and a Low Protein Diet
field_search_summary_text: For those with kidney disease on a low-protein diet, pasta can be a helpful addition. Opt for low-protein pasta and watch for sodium and phosphorus in sauces to stay within dietary limits.

title: Taking Care of Your Peritoneal Dialysis (PD) Catheter
field_search_summary_text: Proper care of your PD catheter is key to preventing infections and ensuring effective treatment. Follow cleaning and monitoring guidelines to maintain catheter function.

title: Inserting Your Own Needles for Dialysis (Self-Cannulation) Is Your Right!
field_search_summary_text: Self-cannulation for dialysis is your right and can offer greater control and convenience. It requires proper training and practice. Talk to your care team to see if it's right for you.

title: Complement 3 Glomerulopathy (C3G): Knowing the Signs and Symptoms
field_search_summary_text: C3G symptoms vary and include blood in urine, proteinuria, swelling, gout, and high blood pressure. Eye problems and abnormal fat distribution may also occur.

title: How Does Palliative Care Improve the Quality of Life for Kidney Patients?
field_search_summary_text: Palliative care supports kidney patients by managing symptoms, easing emotional stress, and improving quality of life. It's available at any stage and complements other treatments.

title: Kidney Atrophy
field_search_summary_text: Kidney atrophy means smaller kidneys. It has multiple causes. One or both kidneys can be impacted.

title: How Much Plant-Based Protein Can You Eat Based on Your Stage of Kidney Disease?
field_search_summary_text: How much plant-based protein you need depends on your kidney disease stage. Dialysis patients need more; pre-dialysis need less. Consult a dietitian for personalized advice.

title: Myths and Misconceptions About Plant-Based Diets
field_search_summary_text: Myths about plant-based diets debunked: it's not about giving up all animal products, it's cost-effective, and can fit into social and dining situations.

title: How to Stock a Plant-Based Pantry
field_search_summary_text: Stock your plant-based pantry with whole grains, legumes, nuts, seeds, soy products, and healthy oils. Choose unsalted items and avoid high potassium substitutes.

title: The Beginner's Guide to Starting a Plant-Based Diet (When You Have Kidney Disease)
field_search_summary_text: Switching  to a plant-based eating by focusing on fruits, veggies, and legumes. Swap animal proteins for plant options and monitor sodium and potassium.

title: What is a Plant-Based Diet, and Is It Good For Your Kidneys?
field_search_summary_text: Plant-based diets focus on whole grains, fruits, and veggies, and may benefit kidney health. They can help manage weight, blood pressure, and diabetes.

title: Plant-Based Diet or Vegetarian Diet – What is the Difference?
field_search_summary_text: Plant-based diets focus on whole grains, fruits, and veggies, while vegetarian diets exclude meat but may include dairy and eggs. Both can be healthy for kidney disease if planned carefully.

title: Writing to Donor Families and Living Donors: A Simple Guide for Kidney Transplant Recipients
field_search_summary_text: Guide for kidney recipients on writing to donors or families: share your transplant experience, maintain confidentiality, and follow sending instructions.

title: Writing to Transplant Recipients: A Guide for Donor Families and Living Donors
field_search_summary_text: Guidelines for donor families and living donors on writing letters to transplant recipients. Tips on what to include and how to ensure confidentiality.

title: Can Plant-Based Diets Help Prevent Kidney Disease for People with Type 2 Diabetes?
field_search_summary_text: Plant-based diets, like those with soy protein, may reduce kidney disease risk in Type 2 diabetes and offer other health benefits

title: Are Contact Sports OK for Kids with Kidney Disease?
field_search_summary_text: Contact sports are generally safe for kids with kidney disease, but risks vary. Consult your child's healthcare professional for personalized advice and consider protective gear if needed.

title: CKD Diet: How much protein is the right amount?
field_search_summary_text: If you have CKD, limit protein if not on dialysis and increase protein if on dialysis. Consult a dietitian for your specific protein needs.

title: The Dental / Kidney Disease Connection
field_search_summary_text: Good dental care is crucial for people with kidney disease. Infections from dental issues can worsen kidney health. Regular check-ups and good hygiene are essential.

title: Hepatitis C and Chronic Kidney Disease: Overview of Evaluation and Management
field_search_summary_text: Hepatitis C virus infection  can cause liver issues and accelerate CKD progression. Learn about HCV's impact on CKD, screening methods, and the latest treatment options for better management.

title: C3G Patient Resources
field_search_summary_text: C3G is a rare kidney disease with a lifelong impact. Explore our resources for understanding, diagnosing, and treating C3G. Visit our community for support.

title: Nutrition and Kidney Failure
field_search_summary_text: Eating healthy is important if you have kidney failure. Good nutrition gives you the energy to do your daily tasks, prevent infection, build and keep muscle, and help you stay at a healthy body weight.

title: HIV and Kidney Transplantation/Donation
field_search_summary_text: People with HIV can receive or donate kidneys if their viral load is undetectable and CD4 count is above 200. Learn more about the HOPE Act and criteria.

title: Quick Facts: Gout and Chronic Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Gout and CKD are linked: gout raises CKD risk and vice versa. Learn about symptoms, diagnosis, and risk factors.

title: Complement 3 Glomerulopathy (C3G)
field_search_summary_text: C3G is complement 3 glomerulopathy, where kidney filters (glomeruli) are damaged due to abnormal activity of the complement 3 protein.

title: Refractory Gout
field_search_summary_text: Refractory gout causes painful joints and is hard to treat.

title: Nephropathic Cystinosis
field_search_summary_text: Nephropathic cystinosis is a rare, inherited disorder causing cystine buildup. It can affect kidneys, eyes, and other organs, with treatments improving longevity.

title: Refractory Gout Management
field_search_summary_text: Refractory gout causes painful joints and is hard to treat. Managing it includes medicine, healthy eating, and exercise, especially if you have kidney disease.

title: Nephropathic Cystinosis: Evaluation and Management
field_search_summary_text: Evaluation and management of nephropathic cystinosis, including diagnosis, treatment with cysteamine, and lifelong care strategies.

title: Living Donation: What Is Informed Consent And Why Do I Need It To Become A Living Kidney Donor?
field_search_summary_text: Learn about informed consent for living kidney donation. Understand why it's essential for donors to make informed decisions and the process involved.

title: Maintaining a Vegetarian Diet with Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: A vegetarian diet can be safe and beneficial for kidney disease patients with careful planning. Focus on managing protein, sodium, potassium, and phosphorus intake.

title: Tips to Tackling the DASH Diet
field_search_summary_text: Discover tips for following the DASH diet to lower kidney and heart disease risk. Focus on reducing sodium, increasing fruits and veggies, and choosing low-fat dairy.

title: Evaluation for Kidney Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Learn about the thorough evaluation process for kidney transplants, including medical, psychosocial, and compatibility tests to determine if you're a suitable candidate.

title: Diabetes: Ten Tips for Self-Management
field_search_summary_text: Managing diabetes daily is crucial. Eat healthy, stay active, take medications, and monitor your health. Get tested for kidney disease annually. Learn and stay informed.

title: Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD)
field_search_summary_text: PTLD is a serious post-transplant condition where white blood cells multiply abnormally, potentially leading to lymphoma. Early detection and treatment are crucial.

title: Secondary Hyperparathyroidism
field_search_summary_text: Secondary hyperparathyroidism is when your parathyroid glands release too much PTH due to kidney problems, causing weak bones and calcium buildup in your body.

title: Insurance Options for Kidney Patients
field_search_summary_text: Find out more information about insurance options for kidney patients.

title: Insurance Options
field_search_summary_text: Find out more information about insurance options for kidney patients.

title: Insurance Options for People on Dialysis or With a Kidney Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Find out information about insurance options for kidney patients, dialysis treatment, and transplant.

title: FAQ About Medicare for Kidney Patients
field_search_summary_text: Find out more information about Medicare for kidney patients.

title: Understanding your lab values and other CKD health numbers
field_search_summary_text: Learn about your CKD health numbers: blood pressure, weight, serum creatinine, eGFR, BUN, uACR, and more. Regular testing helps manage CKD.

title: The DASH Diet
field_search_summary_text: The DASH Diet helps manage high blood pressure and kidney disease with fruits, veggies, whole grains, and low-fat dairy. Discover more about its benefits.

title: Preemptive Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Explore the benefits of preemptive kidney transplants, including reduced rejection risk, improved quality of life, and avoiding dialysis.

title: Know Your Kidney Numbers: Two Simple Tests
field_search_summary_text: Know your kidney numbers with two tests: eGFR (blood test) checks kidney filtration, and uACR (urine test) checks for protein. Early detection is key.

title: Kidney Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Transplant is a treatment for kidney failure using a healthy kidney from a living or deceased donor that can help patients live a longer, more normal life than dialysis treatment.

title: Kidney Diseases Clinical Trial Directory
field_search_summary_text: Participating in kidney disease clinical trials helps research new treatments. Find opportunities and ask your healthcare provider about local studies.

title: Who Can Participate In a Clinical Trial?
field_search_summary_text: To join a clinical trial, you need to meet certain rules like age, gender, and health condition. You must understand the risks and benefits before you join. This is called informed consent.

title: Are Clinical Trials Safe?
field_search_summary_text: Clinical trials are regulated by the FDA and reviewed by independent experts to ensure safety. Each phase of the trial checks the treatment's safety and effectiveness.

title: What is a Clinical Trial?
field_search_summary_text: A clinical trial tests new treatments for efficacy and safety. Led by doctors, these studies help find better ways to prevent, diagnose, or treat diseases.

title: Tips For Your Check-up
field_search_summary_text: Here are some helpful things to discuss with your doctor at your annual physical.

title: What the Color of Your Urine Means
field_search_summary_text: Urine color shows health clues. Clear/pale yellow means hydrated. Dark yellow suggests dehydration. Pink/red see a doctor. Foamy urine may indicate kidney disease.

title: Getting More Protein While on Dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Learn why protein is essential while on dialysis, how to identify low protein levels, and ways to increase dietary protein effectively.

title: Managing Your Emotions While Living with Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Discover how to manage emotions while living with kidney disease. Learn strategies for coping with anxiety, stress, and lifestyle changes.

title: Understanding Glomerular Diseases
field_search_summary_text: Learn about glomerular diseases, including causes, symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment options. Discover how to manage and prevent these kidney conditions.

title: Membranous Nephropathy (MN)
field_search_summary_text: Membranous nephropathy (MN) is a kidney disease where the immune system attacks kidney filters, causing swelling, fatigue, and proteinuria.

title: Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis
field_search_summary_text: MPGN damages kidney glomeruli due to immune system issues. Symptoms: blood/protein in urine, swelling. Treated with meds, dietary changes, and monitoring.

title: Incompatible Blood Types and Paired Exchange Programs
field_search_summary_text: Blood type compatibility is crucial for kidney transplants. Paired exchange programs help if blood types don't match by facilitating swaps between donor-recipient pairs.

title: Multiple Listing for Kidney Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Learn about multiple kidney transplant listings: reasons, evaluations, and potential downsides. Explore your options to increase transplant chances.

title: How to Find a Transplant Center
field_search_summary_text: To find a transplant center, visit the OPTN website, select "Transplant Centers by Organ," choose "Kidney," and then select your state or region.

title: Why You Should Avoid Eating Starfruit
field_search_summary_text: People with kidney disease should avoid starfruit, as it can cause harmful effects like confusion and seizures due to a toxin. Consult your doctor for guidance.

title: Understanding Ectopic Kidneys
field_search_summary_text: An ectopic kidney is a birth defect where a kidney is out of place. It often causes no symptoms but may affect urine flow, leading to complications. Treatment is needed if it causes problems.

title: Dairy and Our Kidneys
field_search_summary_text: Dairy products are rich in protein, calcium, phosphorus, potassium, and B vitamins. For those with decreased kidney function, these nutrients may need to be limited to prevent complications.

title: Six Tips for Managing Your Medications When You're a Teen
field_search_summary_text: Managing medications as a teen with kidney disease can be challenging. Understand your meds, set a routine, stay organized, communicate with your healthcare team, and ask a friend for support.

title: Calcium Oxalate Stones
field_search_summary_text: Calcium oxalate stones are common kidney stones caused by high oxalate levels. Learn about risk factors, prevention tips, and dietary guidelines.

title: Living Donation: Sample Letter to Family and Friends
field_search_summary_text: Craft a personal letter or social media post to share your kidney disease story and the need for a living kidney donor. Include facts, a photo, and contact details.

title: BK Virus: What Transplant Patients Need to Know
field_search_summary_text: BK virus is common and usually inactive in your body, but it can wake up after a transplant, especially with weakened immunity. It may affect the new kidney.

title: Your Kidneys and Iron
field_search_summary_text: Iron is crucial for red blood cells. Kidney disease can cause low iron, leading to anemia. Treatments include diet changes, supplements, and IV iron.

title: Medical Jewelry
field_search_summary_text: Find out how to obtain free or discounted medical jewelry from Medic Alert, American Medical ID, Monroe Specialty Company, and Road ID.

title: Acid Reflux and Proton Pump Inhibitors
field_search_summary_text: Acid reflux happens when stomach acid causes chest pain. GERD is severe and may need PPIs. PPIs can affect kidneys, so talk to your doctor if you have kidney issues.

title: Cystine Stones
field_search_summary_text: Cystine stones are kidney stones caused by the inherited disorder cystinuria. They can cause pain, blood in urine, and may require treatment like increased water intake, dietary changes, or surgery.

title: Lead Exposure and Kidney Function
field_search_summary_text: Learn how lead exposure affects kidney function, risks for children, and what to do if youâ€™re pregnant or worried about lead in your water or environment.

title: HIV and Chronic Kidney Disease: What You Need to Know
field_search_summary_text: HIV can increase the risk of kidney disease. Regular testing, managing blood pressure, and taking prescribed medications can help protect your kidney health.

title: Fluid Overload in a Dialysis Patient
field_search_summary_text: Fluid overload in dialysis patients occurs when too much water builds up in the body. It can cause swelling, high blood pressure, breathing problems, and heart issues.

title: When Kidneys Stop Working
field_search_summary_text: When kidneys fail, treatments like dialysis or transplant are needed. Dialysis cleans your blood with a machine, while a transplant gives you a healthy kidney from a donor.

title: All About Kidneys - Basics for Kids
field_search_summary_text: Learn about kidneys, their functions, and how to keep them healthy. Discover what kidney disease feels like and why it's important to care for your kidneys.

title: Advance Directives For Children and Adolescents
field_search_summary_text: Advance directives help ensure your medical care preferences are respected if you can't communicate. They include living wills and health care proxies.

title: Simple Kidney Vocabulary List
field_search_summary_text: Here are simple kidney vocabulary words you should know.

title: Better Kidney Health for Kids: Seven Golden Rules
field_search_summary_text: Seven tips to support kids' kidney health: exercise, reduce sugar and salt, serve water, maintain weight, use meds properly, and get regular checkups.

title: Childhood Infections & Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Childhood infections like strep and UTIs can harm kidneys.

title: Hyperkalemia (high potassium)
field_search_summary_text: Hyperkalemia is high potassium in the blood, often caused by kidney disease. Symptoms include muscle weakness and heart issues. Treatment includes diet changes and medication.

title: Heart Health: Ten Tips to Keep Your Heart Healthy on Dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Follow these tips to keep your heart healthy on dialysis: control blood sugar and blood pressure, maintain a heart-healthy diet, exercise, treat anemia, and reduce stress.

title: What Is Dry Weight?
field_search_summary_text: Dry weight is your weight without extra fluid. It's important for dialysis patients to monitor this, as extra fluid can strain your heart and lungs.

title: Your Dialysis Care Team
field_search_summary_text: The dialysis care team includes nephrologists, nurses, dietitians, social workers, technicians, and more. Each plays a role in managing your care.

title: What Causes High Blood Pressure?
field_search_summary_text: High blood pressure affects many adults and can go unnoticed. Causes include smoking, being overweight, and inactivity. Regular checkups can help manage it.

title: Low-Protein Recipes
field_search_summary_text: Discover low protein recipes for kidney disease. Learn how to structure a low protein diet and explore delicious, kidney-friendly food options.

title: Smoking and Your Health
field_search_summary_text: Smoking is the top preventable cause of death in the U.S. It raises risks for various cancers, heart disease, and kidney problems.

title: Simple Kidney Cysts
field_search_summary_text: Simple kidney cysts are fluid-filled sacs that usually don't cause issues. If symptomatic, they can be treated with drainage or laparoscopic surgery.

title: Reflux Disorders in Children
field_search_summary_text: Reflux in children is when urine backs up from the bladder to the kidney. It often follows infections and may need antibiotics or surgery.

title: Helping Children Adjust When a Parent Has Kidney Failure
field_search_summary_text: Kidney failure affects the whole family. Open communication with children is important. Address their concerns honestly and seek help if needed.

title: Prostate Cancer
field_search_summary_text: Prostate cancer is common in men and often curable if detected early. Regular checkups are essential as early stages have no symptoms.

title: Preventing Diabetic Kidney Disease: 10 Answers to Questions
field_search_summary_text: Prevent diabetic kidney disease with good blood sugar control. Regular checkups, a healthy lifestyle, and medication can help protect your kidneys and overall health.

title: Pregnancy and Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Pregnancy with kidney disease or transplant requires careful planning. Discuss risks, treatments, and health impacts with your doctor for a safe pregnancy

title: Polycystic Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) causes fluid-filled cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney damage and failure. Learn about symptoms, risks, and treatments.

title: Plasmapheresis and Blood-type Incompatible Kidney Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Plasmapheresis lets kidney transplants from incompatible blood types by removing harmful antibodies. Learn about this advanced treatment option.

title: Planning for Emergencies - A Guide for People with Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Be prepared for emergencies with a guide tailored for kidney disease patients. Learn to manage your treatment, maintain supplies, and follow safety tips during crises.

title: Phosphorus and Your Diet
field_search_summary_text: Phosphorus is a mineral found in your bones. Along with calcium, phosphorus is needed to build strong healthy bones, as well as, keeping other parts of your body healthy.

title: Peritoneal Dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Peritoneal dialysis uses the lining of your belly to filter blood when kidneys fail. Learn about the process, types, pros and cons, and payment options.

title: Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy / Nephrolithotripsy
field_search_summary_text: Procedures for removing large kidney stones through a small incision. Effective and less invasive than open surgery. Risks include infection and bleeding.

title: Urine albumin-creatinine ratio (uACR)
field_search_summary_text: Learn about the urine albumin-creatinine ratio (uACR) test, which measures albumin and creatinine in urine to assess kidney health and detect potential kidney disease.

title: What You Should Know About Infectious Diseases: A Guide for Hemodialysis Patients and Their Families
field_search_summary_text: Hemodialysis patients should be aware of infectious diseases, as kidney failure can weaken the immune system and increase the risk of infection. Learn how to protect your health.

title: What You Should Know About Good Nutrition
field_search_summary_text: Want better health? Good nutrition and exercise can help. Explore food groups, smart shopping, and the role of vitamins and minerals.

title: What You Should Know About Blood Lipids
field_search_summary_text: Blood lipids, including cholesterol and triglycerides, are fats that affect heart health. Maintain healthy levels through diet, exercise, and medication if needed.

title: What Is High Blood Pressure?
field_search_summary_text: High blood pressure, affecting one in three adults, is caused by factors like smoking, obesity, and lack of exercise. Regular checkups are vital for detection and management.

title: Kidney Biopsy
field_search_summary_text: A kidney biopsy removes a small tissue sample to diagnose kidney disease or assess transplant function, using a needle or open surgery for collection.

title: Vitamins and Minerals in Chronic Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Are you getting enough vitamins and minerals for your health? If you have chronic kidney disease or kidney failure, here’s what you need to know.

title: Urinary Tract Infections
field_search_summary_text: Urinary tract infections (UTIs) can harm your kidneys if untreated. Learn about symptoms, treatments, and prevention to protect your kidney health.

title: Nutrition for Children with Chronic Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Children with chronic kidney disease need tailored diets for growth, focusing on protein, phosphorus, sodium, potassium, and fluid based on their treatment stage.

title: Urinary Incontinence
field_search_summary_text: Explore urinary incontinence causes, symptoms, and treatments. Discover how to manage it with medications, exercises, and surgery.

title: Nutrition and Peritoneal Dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Learn about diet changes for peritoneal dialysis, including managing protein, calories, potassium, sodium, phosphorus, and vitamins to maintain balance and health.

title: Ureteroscopy
field_search_summary_text: Ureteroscopy uses a small scope to diagnose and treat urinary tract issues, like removing stones. It's an outpatient procedure with a low risk of infection or injury.

title: Nutrition and Hemodialysis
field_search_summary_text: On hemodialysis, diet is crucial. You'll need to limit fluids and adjust your intake of certain foods. Your dietitian will guide you in balancing protein, calories, and nutrients.

title: Nutrition and Kidney Disease, Stages 1-5 (Not on Dialysis)
field_search_summary_text: Good nutrition helps people with kidney disease stay healthy. If your kidneys are not working so well, some changes in the diet help you feel better.

title: Nocturnal Hemodialysis
field_search_summary_text: Nocturnal hemodialysis is a longer, gentler treatment done at night, allowing more daytime freedom. Benefits include better waste removal and less dietary restriction.

title: Nephrotic Syndrome
field_search_summary_text: Nephrotic syndrome causes protein loss in urine, leading to swelling and foamy urine. Diagnosis involves tests; treatment focuses on symptoms and underlying causes.

title: Nephrectomy
field_search_summary_text: Nephrectomy is the surgical removal of a kidney. It treats kidney cancer or removes a healthy kidney for transplant. Recovery and risks vary by procedure type.

title: Travel Tips: A Guide for Kidney Patients
field_search_summary_text: Traveling with dialysis or a kidney transplant is possible and can be beneficial. Plan ahead, consult your doctor, and coordinate treatments for a safe trip.

title: Thin Basement Membrane Disease
field_search_summary_text: Thin Basement Membrane Disease is a rare inherited kidney disorder affecting glomeruli, causing hematuria and proteinuria. It typically has a benign course with good prognosis.

title: The Buttonhole Technique
field_search_summary_text: The buttonhole technique uses dull needles in the same spots on a fistula for less pain and fewer complications. Consult your healthcare provider for details.

title: Take Steps to Keep Your Heart Healthy on Dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Manage heart health on dialysis with a heart-healthy diet, regular exercise, and medical treatments. Control blood pressure, cholesterol, and blood sugar levels.

title: Staying Fit With Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Exercise is important for people with kidney disease. It improves strength, energy, and overall health. Always consult your doctor before starting any exercise program.

title: Spice Up Your Diet
field_search_summary_text: Explore seasoning recipes and spice tips to add flavor without salt. Enhance your meals with blends and spices tailored for kidney health.

title: Minimal Change Disease
field_search_summary_text: Minimal Change Disease (MCD) affects kidney filters, causing foamy urine and swelling. Common in kids, it's usually treated with steroids.

title: Mineral and Bone Disorder
field_search_summary_text: Mineral and bone disorder occurs in kidney disease due to imbalances in calcium and phosphorus. Symptoms include bone pain and heart issues. Treatment includes diet, meds, and exercise.

title: Metabolic Syndrome after Kidney Transplantation: Are You at Risk?
field_search_summary_text: Learn about metabolic syndrome after a kidney transplant, its risks, and effective lifestyle changes to manage and prevent this condition for better health outcomes.

title: Medullary Sponge Kidney
field_search_summary_text: Medullary Sponge Kidney (MSK) is a rare congenital disorder where small cysts form in the kidneys, possibly leading to urinary tract infections and kidney stones.

title: Living With One Kidney
field_search_summary_text: Most people live healthy lives with one kidney, but it’s important to stay healthy and protect that kidney.

title: Lithotripsy
field_search_summary_text: Shock wave lithotripsy is a way to break up kidney stones without surgery. High-energy waves break the stones into tiny pieces that can pass in your urine.

title: Lithium and Chronic Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Lithium is used to treat mood disorders but may harm kidneys with long-term use. It can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, leading to increased urination and thirst.

title: Sodium and Your CKD Diet: How to Spice Up Your Cooking
field_search_summary_text: Learn how to limit sodium in your CKD diet. Use herbs and spices for flavor instead of salt to manage blood pressure and fluid balance.

title: Your Transplant Care Team
field_search_summary_text: Your transplant care team includes a physician, surgeon, coordinator, pharmacist, social worker, dietitian, and financial counselor, plus the National Kidney Foundation.

title: Your Guide to the New and Improved Nutrition Facts Label
field_search_summary_text: Learn about the new Nutrition Facts Label to manage your kidney diet. Check serving sizes, calories, fat, sodium, carbs, protein, potassium, and phosphorus.

title: Your Child Has Hydronephrosis
field_search_summary_text: Hydronephrosis is kidney swelling due to urine buildup, often found in prenatal ultrasounds. It's monitored and may need treatment after birth.

title: Working With Kidney Disease: Rehabilitation and Employment
field_search_summary_text: Managing work with CKD? You might need adjustments or time off for treatment. Know your job rights, consider disability benefits, and use job resources.

title: Which Drugs are Harmful to Your Kidneys?
field_search_summary_text: Certain drugs, including painkillers, antibiotics, and illegal substances, can harm your kidneys. Always follow your healthcare provider's instructions and avoid unsupervised medication use.

title: Kidneys: Master Chemists of the Body
field_search_summary_text: Kidneys filter waste and maintain body balance. Kidney disease can affect overall health.

title: Kidney-Pancreas Transplant
field_search_summary_text: A kidney-pancreas transplant can treat kidney failure from type 1 diabetes. Learn who can get it, how it works, and what to expect before and after surgery.

title: Kidney Stone Treatment: Shock Wave Lithotripsy
field_search_summary_text: Shock Wave Lithotripsy (SWL) is the most common kidney stone treatment in the U.S., using shock waves to break stones into tiny pieces for easier passage.

title: Keeping in Control: Lowering Your Risk for Kidney and Heart Disease
field_search_summary_text: Manage blood glucose to reduce risks of kidney and heart disease. Regular check-ups, a healthy lifestyle, and monitoring can help keep you safe.

title: Anemia and Iron Needs in Dialysis
field_search_summary_text: People on dialysis may have iron deficiency anemia due to blood loss during treatments and a low iron diet. Symptoms include pale skin, low energy, and shortness of breath. ESAs and extra iron can help.

title: Interstitial Cystitis
field_search_summary_text: Interstitial cystitis (IC) causes bladder pain and frequent urination. It's common in women but can affect anyone. No cure exists, but treatments can help manage symptoms.

title: Impotence
field_search_summary_text: Impotence affects many men and can be caused by diseases, medications, or emotional issues. Treatments include counseling, medications, vacuum pumps, and possibly surgery.

title: If You Choose Not to Start Dialysis Treatment
How is High Blood Pressure Treated?
field_search_summary_text: High blood pressure is managed with lifestyle changes and medications. Follow your healthcare provider's plan to keep it under control and prevent complications.

title: Home Hemodialysis
field_search_summary_text: Being diagnosed with kidney failure can be overwhelming. Learn about treatment options and stay involved in your care decisions to help manage this challenging time.

title: High Blood Pressure: The Role of the Family
field_search_summary_text: Support family members with high blood pressure by adopting a healthy diet, exercising together, and quitting smoking. Encourage medication adherence and regular checks.

title: High Blood Pressure and Kidney Disease in Children
field_search_summary_text: High blood pressure is common in kids with CKD and can worsen the condition. Early detection and treatment are crucial. Learn more about managing blood pressure in children with CKD.

title: Seasoning Recipes
field_search_summary_text: Explore seasoning recipes and spice tips to add flavor without salt. Enhance your meals with blends and spices tailored for kidney health.

title: Herbal Supplements and Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Patients with kidney disease should be cautious with herbal supplements as some can affect kidney health and interact with medications.

title: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)
field_search_summary_text: Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) damages blood vessels, causing low platelets, anemia, and kidney failure. It can also harm other organs like the brain and heart.

title: Hemodialysis Catheters: How to Keep Yours Working Well
field_search_summary_text: Hemodialysis catheters help clean your blood when kidneys fail. Learn how to care for your catheter to prevent infections and keep blood flowing well.

title: Hemodialysis Access
field_search_summary_text: Hemodialysis access is a way to reach the blood for dialysis. Types include fistula, graft, and catheter. Care includes hygiene and checking for problems.

title: Health Care Team
field_search_summary_text: Your kidney care team includes doctors, nurses, dietitians, social workers, and technicians. Each plays a vital role in your treatment and support.

title: What is Glomerulonephritis?
field_search_summary_text: Glomerulonephritis is a group of diseases that harm the kidney's blood filters (glomeruli). This can lead to kidney failure if untreated. Learn more about its impact on kidney function.

title: Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR)
field_search_summary_text: Learn about eGFR, how your kidneys filter waste, and why early detection of CKD is crucial for protecting kidney health.

title: Food Safety is a Must!
field_search_summary_text: Food safety is crucial for transplant patients to prevent foodborne illnesses. Key principles: Clean, Separate, Cook, Chill. Avoid high-risk foods and follow safety guidelines.

title: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)
field_search_summary_text: Learn about FSGS, a kidney disease causing scarring in glomeruli. Understand its causes, symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment options. Stay informed about managing FSGS.

title: Fluoride
field_search_summary_text: Fluoride’s impact on CKD is unclear due to limited research. It helps prevent tooth decay but may cause rare bone issues. Check the provided documents for details.

title: Five Surprising Ways You Could Be Damaging Your Kidneys
field_search_summary_text: Learn five surprising ways you could be harming your kidneys, including overuse of NSAIDs, smoking, high sodium intake, exposure to contrast dye, and excessive cola consumption.

title: Dialysis Myths from Facts
field_search_summary_text: Debunk common dialysis myths: pain, cost, travel, work, and patient control. Learn the facts to manage your treatment and stay informed.

title: Fabry Disease
field_search_summary_text: Fabry disease is a rare genetic disorder causing dangerous fat buildup in cells due to a missing enzyme, leading to kidney, heart, and brain issues.

title: Employers' Guide
field_search_summary_text: Support employees with end stage renal disease (ESRD) by understanding treatment options, necessary workplace adjustments, and legal protections.

title: Emergency Meal Planning for Diabetic Patients on Dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Plan for emergencies to manage diabetes and health if you skip dialysis. Store non-perishable food, medications, and essential supplies.

title: Emergency Meal Planning for Patients on Dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Have an emergency meal plan to take care of your health if you miss dialysis. Keep non-perishable food, medications, and essential supplies on hand.

title: Dining Out With Confidence - On Dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Dining out on dialysis? Plan ahead, watch protein, salt, potassium, and fluids. Choose smaller portions and consult your dietitian for best options.

title: Dialysis: Deciding to Stop
field_search_summary_text: If considering stopping dialysis, discuss it with your healthcare team and loved ones. Understand the medical and emotional implications before deciding.

title: Dialysis Facility Complaints: Your Rights and Responsibilities
field_search_summary_text: Learn your rights and responsibilities as a dialysis patient, including how to address complaints and ensure quality care. Find support and guidance here.

title: Dialysis
field_search_summary_text: Learn about dialysis, a treatment to remove extra fluid and waste when kidneys fail. Discover types, processes, and ways to manage dialysis effectively.

title: Diabetes and Kidney Disease Stage 5
field_search_summary_text: How diabetes impacts kidney function in Stage 5 CKD. Managing blood sugar, blood pressure, and diet to protect your kidneys.

title: Diabetes - A Major Risk Factor for Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Learn how diabetes increases the risk of kidney disease. Understand the signs of kidney damage, prevention strategies, and treatment options.

title: Detecting Kidney and Urinary Tract Abnormalities Before Birth
field_search_summary_text: Ultrasound can detect kidney and urinary tract abnormalities before birth. Many do not impact overall health, but some may need treatment after delivery.

title: Cystatin C
field_search_summary_text: Cystatin C is a protein made by your body. Healthy kidneys keep its level balanced. High levels of cystatin C in your blood might mean your kidneys aren't working well.

title: Coping Effectively: A Guide for Patients and their Families
field_search_summary_text: Despite medical advances, kidney failure deeply affects daily life and emotions. Learn about the challenges and support available for patients and families.

title: Contrast Dye and the Kidneys
field_search_summary_text: Contrast dyes used in tests like MRIs and CT scans can harm kidneys, especially in people with kidney disease. Learn how to reduce your risk.

title: Chronic Kidney Disease and Pneumococcal Disease: Do You Know the Facts?
field_search_summary_text: Stay up-to-date with pneumococcal vaccines if you have kidney disease or a transplant. These vaccines protect against serious infections like pneumonia, meningitis, and sepsis.

title: Cholesterol, Fats, and Heart Disease: What You Need to Know
field_search_summary_text: Understand how cholesterol impacts kidney health and increases heart disease risk in CKD. Learn how to manage cholesterol and protect your kidneys.

title: Children With Chronic Kidney Disease: Tips for Parents
field_search_summary_text: Tips for parents of children with chronic kidney disease: Learn about CKD, engage in care, manage diet and medication, and seek support from others.

title: Childhood Nephrotic Syndrome
field_search_summary_text: Childhood nephrotic syndrome, also called nephrosis, causes too much protein in urine, weight gain, and swelling. It affects kids' kidneys and is treatable.

title: Brain Death
field_search_summary_text: Brain death is the complete and irreversible loss of all brain function. It is diagnosed through clinical tests and confirmed by medical guidelines.

title: Blood Tests for Transplant
field_search_summary_text: Antibodies can help protect you from illness, but they can also cause kidney transplant rejection. Learn about your options, cross-matching, and clinical trials for transplantation.

title: Benign Prostate Disease
field_search_summary_text: Enlarged prostate affects urine flow, common in older men. Symptoms include weak stream and frequent urination. Treatments vary from meds to surgery.

title: Antibodies and Transplantation: Everything You Wanted to Know and More
field_search_summary_text: Learn about the role of antibodies in kidney transplantation, including how they can impact transplant compatibility, options for those with high antibody levels, and treatment options.

title: Anemia and Chronic Kidney Disease
field_search_summary_text: Anemia in CKD is common due to low EPO. Symptoms include fatigue and dizziness. Treatment involves ESAs and iron supplements. Regular blood tests are key.

title: Alport Syndrome
field_search_summary_text: Alport syndrome is a genetic disease causing kidney damage, hearing loss, and eye problems. Learn about its symptoms, diagnosis, and treatments for kidney health.

title: Alcohol and Your Kidneys
field_search_summary_text: Drinking alcohol can harm kidneys, leading to high blood pressure, dehydration, and liver disease. Limit alcohol intake to protect kidney health.

title: Albuminuria (proteinuria)
field_search_summary_text: Albuminuria (sometimes referred to as proteinuria) is when you have albumin in your urine.

title: Advance Directives
field_search_summary_text: Guide your medical care with an advance directive. Specify your treatment wishes for future crises to ensure your preferences are respected when you can't speak.

title: Six Easy Ways to Prevent Kidney Stones
field_search_summary_text: Did you know 1 in 10 people will have a kidney stone in their lifetime? Kidney stone rates are rising. Learn the facts and myths to stay stone-free.

title: Five Sneaky Sources of Sugar
field_search_summary_text: Many common foods contain hidden sugar that can impact kidney health. Watch out for condiments, breakfast cereals, white bread, high-fructose corn syrup, and soft drinks.

title: Choosing A Treatment For Kidney Failure
field_search_summary_text: Learn about kidney failure treatments: hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis, and kidney transplant. Understand each option to make informed choices with your healthcare team.
